intro: Galium subvelutinum subsp. decumbens, commonly known as creeping bedstraw, is a low-growing herbaceous plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate or decumbent growth habit. The plant features small, opposite leaves that are usually hairy and have a slightly waxy texture. Its flowers are white or pale pink, arranged in clusters, and bloom during the spring and early summer. It thrives in moist, shady environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
